Erosion is a natural process involving the removal, transportation, and accumulation of soil, rock, or sediment from one location to another. It occurs due to various agents such as water, wind, ice, or gravity. As these materials are transported by erosion, they eventually settle and accumulate in new locations through a process known as deposition.

Deposition happens when the forces carrying the eroded materials lose energy and can no longer support the transport of these particles. This loss of energy can occur due to a decrease in velocity, such as when a river flows into a larger body of water and slows down, depositing the sediments it carries. Similarly, wind losing its strength can drop the sediment it has been carrying, leading to accumulation in a new area. In the case of glaciers, melting can deposit the rocks and soils that were encased in the ice.

The materials deposited can vary greatly in size, from fine particles like silt and clay to larger boulders and rocks. The location and nature of the deposited materials depend on the method of erosion and the environment where deposition occurs. Over time, these accumulated materials can form various geological features, such as deltas, sand dunes, and alluvial fans, significantly altering landscapes and creating new habitats for ecosystems.
